In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here's how you can write the function `audi_filter` in Julia, assuming you have the DataFrame `df_cars`:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df)
    filtered_df = df[(df[:manufacturer]] .== "audi") .& 
                           ((df[:model]] .== "a4") .| 
                           (df[:model] .== "a4 quattro")),:]
    
    filtered_df[!,:audi_a4_ type] = true
    
    return filtered_df
end
```

This function first filters the DataFrame based on the given conditions. Then it creates a new column `audi_a4_type` and assigns the value `true` across all rows.

Remember to make sure you have loaded the `DataFrames` package before running this code.
